trans-unit.source: Table design in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Table design in SQL Data Warehouse | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Tips for designing tables in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.
trans-unit.target: Tips for designing tables in Azure SQL Data Warehouse for developing solutions.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse is a massively parallel processing (MPP) distributed database system.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse is a massively parallel processing (MPP) distributed database system.

trans-unit.source: Consequently, it stores data across many different locations known as distributions.
trans-unit.target: Consequently, it stores data across many different locations known as distributions.

trans-unit.source: Each distribution is like a bucket; storing a unique subset of the data in the data warehouse.
trans-unit.target: Each distribution is like a bucket; storing a unique subset of the data in the data warehouse.

trans-unit.source: By spreading the data and processing capability across multiple nodes SQL Data Warehouse is able to offer huge scalability - far beyond any single system.
trans-unit.target: By spreading the data and processing capability across multiple nodes SQL Data Warehouse is able to offer huge scalability - far beyond any single system.

trans-unit.source: When a table is created in SQL Data Warehouse, it is actually spread across all of the the distributions.
trans-unit.target: When a table is created in SQL Data Warehouse, it is actually spread across all of the the distributions.

trans-unit.source: This article will cover the following topics:
trans-unit.target: This article will cover the following topics:

trans-unit.source: Supported data types
trans-unit.target: Supported data types

trans-unit.target: Principles of data distribution

trans-unit.target: Round Robin Distribution

trans-unit.target: Hash Distribution

trans-unit.target: Table Partitioning

trans-unit.source: Unsupported features
trans-unit.target: Unsupported features

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse supports the common business data types:
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse supports the common business data types:

trans-unit.source: bigint
trans-unit.target: bigint

trans-unit.source: binary
trans-unit.target: binary

trans-unit.source: bit
trans-unit.target: bit

trans-unit.source: char
trans-unit.target: char

trans-unit.source: date
trans-unit.target: date

trans-unit.source: datetime
trans-unit.target: datetime

trans-unit.source: datetime2
trans-unit.target: datetime2

trans-unit.source: datetimeoffset
trans-unit.target: datetimeoffset

trans-unit.source: decimal
trans-unit.target: decimal

trans-unit.source: float
trans-unit.target: float

trans-unit.source: int
trans-unit.target: int

trans-unit.source: money
trans-unit.target: money

trans-unit.source: nchar
trans-unit.target: nchar

trans-unit.source: nvarchar
trans-unit.target: nvarchar

trans-unit.source: real
trans-unit.target: real

trans-unit.source: smalldatetime
trans-unit.target: smalldatetime

trans-unit.source: smallint
trans-unit.target: smallint

trans-unit.source: smallmoney
trans-unit.target: smallmoney

trans-unit.source: time
trans-unit.target: time

trans-unit.source: tinyint
trans-unit.target: tinyint

trans-unit.source: varbinary
trans-unit.target: varbinary

trans-unit.source: varchar
trans-unit.target: varchar

trans-unit.source: You can identify columns in your data warehouse that contain incompatible types using the following query:
trans-unit.target: You can identify columns in your data warehouse that contain incompatible types using the following query:

trans-unit.source: The query includes any user defined data types which are also not supported.
trans-unit.target: The query includes any user defined data types which are also not supported.

trans-unit.source: If you have unsupported types in your database do not worry.
trans-unit.target: If you have unsupported types in your database do not worry.

trans-unit.source: Some alternatives you can use instead are proposed below.
trans-unit.target: Some alternatives you can use instead are proposed below.

trans-unit.source: Instead of:
trans-unit.target: Instead of:

trans-unit.source: geometry, use a varbinary type
trans-unit.target: geometry, use a varbinary type

trans-unit.source: geography, use a varbinary type
trans-unit.target: geography, use a varbinary type

trans-unit.source: hierarchyid, CLR type not native
trans-unit.target: hierarchyid, CLR type not native

trans-unit.source: image, text, ntext when text based use varchar/nvarchar (smaller the better)
trans-unit.target: image, text, ntext when text based use varchar/nvarchar (smaller the better)

trans-unit.source: nvarchar(max), use varchar(4000) or smaller for better performance
trans-unit.target: nvarchar(max), use varchar(4000) or smaller for better performance

trans-unit.source: numeric, use decimal
trans-unit.target: numeric, use decimal

trans-unit.source: sql_variant, split column into several strongly typed columns
trans-unit.target: sql_variant, split column into several strongly typed columns

trans-unit.source: sysname, use nvarchar(128)
trans-unit.target: sysname, use nvarchar(128)

trans-unit.source: table, convert to temporary tables
trans-unit.target: table, convert to temporary tables

trans-unit.source: timestamp, re-work code to use datetime2 and CURRENT_TIMESTAMP function.
trans-unit.target: timestamp, re-work code to use datetime2 and CURRENT_TIMESTAMP function.

trans-unit.source: Note you cannot have current_timestamp as a default constraint and the value will not automatically update.
trans-unit.target: Note you cannot have current_timestamp as a default constraint and the value will not automatically update.

trans-unit.source: If you need to migrate rowversion values from a timestamp typed column then use BINARY(8) or VARBINARY(8) for NOT NULL or NULL row version values.
trans-unit.target: If you need to migrate rowversion values from a timestamp typed column then use BINARY(8) or VARBINARY(8) for NOT NULL or NULL row version values.

trans-unit.source: varchar(max), use varchar(8000) or smaller for better performance
trans-unit.target: varchar(max), use varchar(8000) or smaller for better performance

trans-unit.source: uniqueidentifier, use varbinary(8)
trans-unit.target: uniqueidentifier, use varbinary(8)

trans-unit.source: user defined types, convert back to their native types where possible
trans-unit.target: user defined types, convert back to their native types where possible

trans-unit.source: xml, use a varchar(8000) or smaller for better performance - split across columns if needed
trans-unit.target: xml, use a varchar(8000) or smaller for better performance - split across columns if needed

trans-unit.source: Partial support:
trans-unit.target: Partial support:

trans-unit.source: Default constraints support literals and constants only.
trans-unit.target: Default constraints support literals and constants only.

trans-unit.source: Non-deterministic expressions or functions, such as GETDATE() or CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Non-deterministic expressions or functions, such as GETDATE() or CURRENT_TIMESTAMP, are not supported.

trans-unit.source: Define your tables so that the maximum possible row size, including the full length of variable length columns, does not exceed 32,767 bytes.
trans-unit.target: Define your tables so that the maximum possible row size, including the full length of variable length columns, does not exceed 32,767 bytes.

trans-unit.source: While you can define a row with variable length data that can exceed this figure, you will not be be able to insert data into the table.
trans-unit.target: While you can define a row with variable length data that can exceed this figure, you will not be be able to insert data into the table.

trans-unit.source: Also, try to limit the size of your variable length columns for even better throughput for running queries.
trans-unit.target: Also, try to limit the size of your variable length columns for even better throughput for running queries.

trans-unit.source: There are two choices for distributing data in SQL Data Warehouse:
trans-unit.target: There are two choices for distributing data in SQL Data Warehouse:

trans-unit.source: Distribute data based on hashing values from a single column
trans-unit.target: Distribute data based on hashing values from a single column

trans-unit.source: Distribute data evenly but randomly
trans-unit.target: Distribute data evenly but randomly

trans-unit.source: Data distribution is decided at the table level.
trans-unit.target: Data distribution is decided at the table level.

trans-unit.source: All tables are distributed so you will have the opportunity to make this decision for each table in your SQL Data Warehouse database.
trans-unit.target: All tables are distributed so you will have the opportunity to make this decision for each table in your SQL Data Warehouse database.

trans-unit.source: The first option is known as round-robin distribution - sometimes known as the random hash.
trans-unit.target: The first option is known as round-robin distribution - sometimes known as the random hash.

trans-unit.source: You can think of this as the default or fail safe option.
trans-unit.target: You can think of this as the default or fail safe option.

trans-unit.source: The second option is known as the hash distribution.
trans-unit.target: The second option is known as the hash distribution.

trans-unit.source: You can consider it an optimized form of data distribution.
trans-unit.target: You can consider it an optimized form of data distribution.

trans-unit.source: It is preferred where clusters of tables share common joining and/or aggregation criteria.
trans-unit.target: It is preferred where clusters of tables share common joining and/or aggregation criteria.

trans-unit.source: Round-Robin distribution is a method of spreading data as evenly as possible across all distributions.
trans-unit.target: Round-Robin distribution is a method of spreading data as evenly as possible across all distributions.

trans-unit.source: Buffers containing rows of data are allocated in turn (hence the name round robin) to each distribution.
trans-unit.target: Buffers containing rows of data are allocated in turn (hence the name round robin) to each distribution.

trans-unit.source: The process is repeated until all data buffers have been allocated.
trans-unit.target: The process is repeated until all data buffers have been allocated.

trans-unit.source: At no stage is the data sorted or ordered in a round robin distributed table.
trans-unit.target: At no stage is the data sorted or ordered in a round robin distributed table.

trans-unit.source: A round robin distribution is sometimes called a random hash for this reason.
trans-unit.target: A round robin distribution is sometimes called a random hash for this reason.

trans-unit.source: The data is simply spread as evenly as possible across the distributions.
trans-unit.target: The data is simply spread as evenly as possible across the distributions.

trans-unit.source: Below is an example of round robin distributed table:
trans-unit.target: Below is an example of round robin distributed table:

trans-unit.source: This is also an example of a round robin distributed table:
trans-unit.target: This is also an example of a round robin distributed table:

trans-unit.source: Notice that the second example above makes no mention of the distribution key.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the second example above makes no mention of the distribution key.

trans-unit.source: Round Robin is the default and so it is not absolutely required.
trans-unit.target: Round Robin is the default and so it is not absolutely required.

trans-unit.source: Being explicit however, is considered to be a good practice as ensures that your peers are aware of your intentions when reviewing the table design.
trans-unit.target: Being explicit however, is considered to be a good practice as ensures that your peers are aware of your intentions when reviewing the table design.

trans-unit.source: This table type is commonly used when there is no obvious key column to hash the data by.
trans-unit.target: This table type is commonly used when there is no obvious key column to hash the data by.

trans-unit.source: It can also be used by smaller or less significant tables where the movement cost may not be so great.
trans-unit.target: It can also be used by smaller or less significant tables where the movement cost may not be so great.

trans-unit.source: Loading data into a round robin distributed table tends to be faster than loading into a hash distributed table.
trans-unit.target: Loading data into a round robin distributed table tends to be faster than loading into a hash distributed table.

trans-unit.source: With a round-robin distributed table there is no need to understand the data or perform the hash prior to loading.
trans-unit.target: With a round-robin distributed table there is no need to understand the data or perform the hash prior to loading.

trans-unit.source: For this reason Round-Robin tables often make good good loading targets.
trans-unit.target: For this reason Round-Robin tables often make good good loading targets.

trans-unit.source: When data is round robin distributed the data is allocated to the distribution at the buffer level.
trans-unit.target: When data is round robin distributed the data is allocated to the distribution at the buffer level.

trans-unit.source: Consider using Round Robin distribution for your table in the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Consider using Round Robin distribution for your table in the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: When there is no obvious joining key
trans-unit.target: When there is no obvious joining key

trans-unit.source: If a candidate hash distribution key is not known
trans-unit.target: If a candidate hash distribution key is not known

trans-unit.source: If the table does not share a common joining key with other tables
trans-unit.target: If the table does not share a common joining key with other tables

trans-unit.source: If the join is less significant than other joins in the query
trans-unit.target: If the join is less significant than other joins in the query

trans-unit.source: When the table is an initial loading table
trans-unit.target: When the table is an initial loading table

trans-unit.source: Hash distribution uses an internal function to spread a dataset across the distributions by hashing a single column.
trans-unit.target: Hash distribution uses an internal function to spread a dataset across the distributions by hashing a single column.

trans-unit.source: When data is hashed there is no explicit order to the data being allocated to a distribution.
trans-unit.target: When data is hashed there is no explicit order to the data being allocated to a distribution.

trans-unit.source: However, the hash itself is a deterministic process.
trans-unit.target: However, the hash itself is a deterministic process.

trans-unit.source: This makes the results of the hash predictable.
trans-unit.target: This makes the results of the hash predictable.

trans-unit.source: For example, hashing an integer column containing the value 10 will always yield the same hash value.
trans-unit.target: For example, hashing an integer column containing the value 10 will always yield the same hash value.

trans-unit.source: This means that *any* hashed integer column containing the value 10 would end up being allocated to the same distribution.
trans-unit.target: This means that *any* hashed integer column containing the value 10 would end up being allocated to the same distribution.

trans-unit.source: This is true even across tables.
trans-unit.target: This is true even across tables.

trans-unit.source: The predictability of the hash is extremely important.
trans-unit.target: The predictability of the hash is extremely important.

trans-unit.source: It means that hash distributing the data can lead to performance improvements when reading data and joining tables together.
trans-unit.target: It means that hash distributing the data can lead to performance improvements when reading data and joining tables together.

trans-unit.source: As you will see below, hash distribution can be very effective for query optimization.
trans-unit.target: As you will see below, hash distribution can be very effective for query optimization.

trans-unit.source: This is why it is considered to be an optimized form of data distribution.
trans-unit.target: This is why it is considered to be an optimized form of data distribution.

trans-unit.source: Remember!
trans-unit.target: Remember!

trans-unit.source: The hash is not based on the value of the data but rather on the type of the data being hashed.
trans-unit.target: The hash is not based on the value of the data but rather on the type of the data being hashed.

trans-unit.source: Below is a table that has been hash distributed by ProductKey.
trans-unit.target: Below is a table that has been hash distributed by ProductKey.

trans-unit.source: When data is hash distributed the data is allocated to the distribution at the row level.
trans-unit.target: When data is hash distributed the data is allocated to the distribution at the row level.

trans-unit.source: Table partitions are supported and easy to define.
trans-unit.target: Table partitions are supported and easy to define.

trans-unit.source: Example SQL Data Warehouse partitioned CREATE TABLE command:
trans-unit.target: Example SQL Data Warehouse partitioned CREATE TABLE command:

trans-unit.source: Notice that there is no partitioning function or scheme in the definition.
trans-unit.target: Notice that there is no partitioning function or scheme in the definition.

trans-unit.source: All that is taken care of when the table is created.
trans-unit.target: All that is taken care of when the table is created.

trans-unit.source: All you have to do is identify the boundary points for the column that is going to be the partitioning key.
trans-unit.target: All you have to do is identify the boundary points for the column that is going to be the partitioning key.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse uses a distributed query optimizer to create the appropriate query plan when users query tables.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse uses a distributed query optimizer to create the appropriate query plan when users query tables.

trans-unit.source: Once created, the query plan provides the strategy and method used by the database to access the data and fulfill the user request.
trans-unit.target: Once created, the query plan provides the strategy and method used by the database to access the data and fulfill the user request.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse's query optimizer is based on cost.
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse's query optimizer is based on cost.

trans-unit.source: In other words it compares various options (plans) based on their relative cost and chooses the most efficient plan available to it.
trans-unit.target: In other words it compares various options (plans) based on their relative cost and chooses the most efficient plan available to it.

trans-unit.source: Consequently, SQL Data Warehouse needs a lot of information to make informed, cost based decisions.
trans-unit.target: Consequently, SQL Data Warehouse needs a lot of information to make informed, cost based decisions.

trans-unit.source: It holds statistics information about the table (for table size) and in database objects known as STATISTICS.
trans-unit.target: It holds statistics information about the table (for table size) and in database objects known as STATISTICS.

trans-unit.source: Statistics are held against single or multiple columns of indexes or tables.
trans-unit.target: Statistics are held against single or multiple columns of indexes or tables.

trans-unit.source: They provide the cost-based optimizer with important information concerning cardinality and selectivity of values.
trans-unit.target: They provide the cost-based optimizer with important information concerning cardinality and selectivity of values.

trans-unit.source: This is of particular interest when the optimizer needs to evaluate JOINs, GROUP BY, HAVING and WHERE clauses in a query.
trans-unit.target: This is of particular interest when the optimizer needs to evaluate JOINs, GROUP BY, HAVING and WHERE clauses in a query.

trans-unit.source: It is therefore very important that the information contained in these statistics objects accurately reflects the current state of the table.
trans-unit.target: It is therefore very important that the information contained in these statistics objects accurately reflects the current state of the table.

trans-unit.source: It is vital to understand that it is the accuracy of the cost that is important.
trans-unit.target: It is vital to understand that it is the accuracy of the cost that is important.

trans-unit.source: If the statistics accurately reflect the state of the table then plans can be compared for lowest cost.
trans-unit.target: If the statistics accurately reflect the state of the table then plans can be compared for lowest cost.

trans-unit.source: If they aren't accurate then SQL Data Warehouse may choose the wrong plan.
trans-unit.target: If they aren't accurate then SQL Data Warehouse may choose the wrong plan.

trans-unit.source: Column-level statistics in SQL Data Warehouse are user-defined.
trans-unit.target: Column-level statistics in SQL Data Warehouse are user-defined.

trans-unit.source: In other words we have to create them ourselves.
trans-unit.target: In other words we have to create them ourselves.

trans-unit.source: As we have just learned, this is not something to overlook.
trans-unit.target: As we have just learned, this is not something to overlook.

trans-unit.source: This is an important difference between SQL Server and SQL Data Warehouse.
trans-unit.target: This is an important difference between SQL Server and SQL Data Warehouse.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server will automatically create statistics when columns are queried.
trans-unit.target: SQL Server will automatically create statistics when columns are queried.

trans-unit.source: By default, SQL Server will also automatically update those statistics.
trans-unit.target: By default, SQL Server will also automatically update those statistics.

trans-unit.source: However, in SQL Data Warehouse statistics need to be created manually and managed manually.
trans-unit.target: However, in SQL Data Warehouse statistics need to be created manually and managed manually.

trans-unit.source: Apply the following recommendations for generating statistics:
trans-unit.target: Apply the following recommendations for generating statistics:

trans-unit.source: Create Single column statistics on columns used in WHERE, JOIN, GROUP BY, ORDER BY and DISTINCT clauses
trans-unit.target: Create Single column statistics on columns used in WHERE, JOIN, GROUP BY, ORDER BY and DISTINCT clauses

trans-unit.source: Generate multi-column statistics on composite clauses
trans-unit.target: Generate multi-column statistics on composite clauses

trans-unit.source: Update statistics periodically.
trans-unit.target: Update statistics periodically.

trans-unit.source: Remember that this is not done automatically!
trans-unit.target: Remember that this is not done automatically!

trans-unit.source: It is common for SQL Server Data Warehouse to rely solely on AUTOSTATS to keep the column statistics up to date.
trans-unit.target: It is common for SQL Server Data Warehouse to rely solely on AUTOSTATS to keep the column statistics up to date.

trans-unit.source: This is not a best practice even for SQL Server data warehouses.
trans-unit.target: This is not a best practice even for SQL Server data warehouses.

trans-unit.source: AUTOSTATS are triggered by a 20% rate of change which for large fact tables containing millions or billions of rows may not be sufficient.
trans-unit.target: AUTOSTATS are triggered by a 20% rate of change which for large fact tables containing millions or billions of rows may not be sufficient.

trans-unit.source: It is therefore always a good idea to keep on top of statistics updates to ensure that the statistics accurately reflect the cardinality of the table.
trans-unit.target: It is therefore always a good idea to keep on top of statistics updates to ensure that the statistics accurately reflect the cardinality of the table.

trans-unit.source: SQL Data Warehouse does not use or support these features:
trans-unit.target: SQL Data Warehouse does not use or support these features:

trans-unit.source: primary keys
trans-unit.target: primary keys

trans-unit.source: foreign keys
trans-unit.target: foreign keys

trans-unit.source: check constraints
trans-unit.target: check constraints

trans-unit.source: unique constraints
trans-unit.target: unique constraints

trans-unit.source: unique indexes
trans-unit.target: unique indexes

trans-unit.source: computed columns
trans-unit.target: computed columns

trans-unit.source: sparse columns
trans-unit.target: sparse columns

trans-unit.source: user-defined types
trans-unit.target: user-defined types

trans-unit.source: indexed views
trans-unit.target: indexed views

trans-unit.source: identities
trans-unit.target: identities

trans-unit.source: sequences
trans-unit.target: sequences

trans-unit.source: triggers
trans-unit.target: triggers

trans-unit.source: synonyms
trans-unit.target: synonyms

trans-unit.target: For more development tips, see <linkText>development overview</linkText><title></title>.
